        Consolidated Content:
The original Palace of Versailles was built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge in 1624. It was later enlarged into a chateau by Louis XIII's chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to further enlarge the palace without destroying the original structure. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden. Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the project after Le Vau's death in 1670.

Analysis:

The original Palace of Versailles was initially built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge in 1624 and was later expanded into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV, the son of Louis XIII, decided to further enlarge the palace without destroying the original structure. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden. Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the project after Le Vau's death in 1670, continuing the expansion and transformation of the palace.

By understanding this historical context, the language model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference abilities by recognizing the sequential actions of Louis XIII and Louis XIV, the involvement of different architects and designers, and the gradual expansion of the palace over time.

Answer:
The original Palace of Versailles was built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge in 1624 and was later enlarged by Louis XIV, who commissioned various architects and designers to transform it into the grand palace we know today.
